contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{one source|date=February 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Archibald Alison | image = Archibald Alison.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = Archibald Alison | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1757|11|13}} | birth_place = [[Edinburgh]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1839|05|17|1757|11|13}} | death_place = [[Colinton]], Edinburgh | resting_place = | occupation = Minister of religion<br>Essayist | language = | nationality = Scottish | ethnicity = | citizenship = Great Britain | education = | alma_mater = [[Glasgow University]]<br>[[Balliol College, Oxford]] | period = | genre = | subject = [[didactic]] and philosophical topics | movement = [[Scottish enlightenment]] | notableworks = ''Essay on the Nature and Principles of Taste'' (1790) | spouse = Dorothea Gregory (m. 1784) (d. 1830) | partner = | children = [[William Pulteney Alison]], physician<br>[[Sir Archibald Alison]], advocate | relatives = Brother-in-law of the physician [[James Gregory (physician)|James Gregory]] | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Archibald Alison''' <small>[[Fellow of the Royal Society of London|FRS]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]]</small> (1757–1839) was a Scottish [[Scottish Episcopal Church|episcopalian]] priest and essayist. ==Early life== He was born at Edinburgh on 13 November 1757, to [[Patrick Alison]],{{dubious|date=December 2010}} the [[Provost (religion)|provost]] of the [[Diocese of Edinburgh]], himself a younger son of an Alison of Newhall, near [[Coupar Angus]]. After studying at the [[University of Glasgow]], where he established his lifelong friendship with [[Dugald Stewart]], and at [[Balliol College, Oxford]], he took orders in the [[Church of England]], and was appointed in 1778 to the [[curacy]] of [[Brancepeth]], near [[Durham]]. In 1784 he married Dorothea, youngest daughter of [[John Gregory (moralist)|Professor Gregory]] of Edinburgh. ==Career== The next twenty years of his life were spent in [[Shropshire]], where he held in succession the livings of [[High Ercall]], [[Roddington]] and [[Kenley, Shropshire|Kenley]]. In 1800 he moved back to Edinburgh, having been appointed senior incumbent of St Paul's Chapel in the [[Cowgate]]. For thirty-four years he filled this position with much ability; his sermons were characterised by quiet beauty of thought and grace of composition. His preaching attracted so many hearers that a new and larger church was built for him. His last years were spent at [[Colinton]] near Edinburgh, where he died on 17 May, 1839. He was interred at [[St John's Episcopal Churchyard]] in Edinburgh. ==Works== Alison published, besides a ''Life of Lord Woodhouselee'', a volume of sermons, which passed through several editions, and a work entitled ''Essays on the Nature and Principles of Taste'' (1790), based on the principle of "association". His elder son, Dr [[William Pulteney Alison]] (1790–1859), was a distinguished Edinburgh medical professor.
